title: Directly Learning Stock Trading Strategies Through Profit Guided Loss Functions
abstract: This paper introduces four novel loss functions designed to enable artificial neural networks to directly learn effective stock trading strategies by accounting for potential profits or losses from buying or shorting stocks. These functions allow models like transformers to generate significant profits on a portfolio of 50 S&P 500 stocks, outperforming reinforcement learning benchmarks and buy-and-hold methods. For instance, the Crossformer model adapted with the best loss function achieved returns of 51.42%, 51.04%, and 48.62% in 2021-2023 test periods, surpassing PPO and DDPG methods.

title: Why Naive 1/N Diversification Is Not So Naive, and How to Beat It?
abstract: This paper provides a theoretical analysis of the 1/N diversification rule in portfolio management. It demonstrates that estimated investment strategies fail to achieve optimal Sharpe ratios in high-dimensional settings relative to sample size, while the 1/N rule proves optimal under a 1-factor model with diversifiable risks as dimensionality increases. The study explores conditions where the 1/N rule can be outperformed: combining it with estimated rules when N is small, and integrating it with anomalies or machine learning portfolios when N is large, conditional on their profitability. The findings explain the practical difficulty in beating the 1/N rule and offer tractable solutions under specific scenarios.

abstract: This survey provides a comprehensive overview of Financial Large Language Models (FinLLMs), covering their evolution from general-domain pretrained language models, techniques such as training methods and fine-tuning, performance evaluations on benchmark tasks, and advanced financial NLP datasets. It discusses opportunities and challenges including hallucination, privacy, and efficiency, and compiles accessible datasets and benchmarks to support AI research in finance.

title: AlphaEval: A Comprehensive and Efficient Evaluation Framework for Formula Alpha Mining
abstract: AlphaEval is a unified evaluation framework for automated formula alpha mining in quantitative investment. It addresses limitations of existing evaluation methods like backtesting (computationally intensive and parameter-sensitive) and correlation metrics (overlooking stability, robustness, diversity, and interpretability). The framework assesses alpha quality across five dimensions: predictive power, temporal stability, robustness to market perturbations, financial logic, and diversity. Experiments show AlphaEval achieves consistency with backtesting while offering broader insights and higher efficiency through parallelizable metrics. It also outperforms single-metric screening approaches. The implementation is open-sourced to promote reproducibility.

title: DeepUnifiedMom: Unified Time-series Momentum Portfolio Construction via Multi-Task Learning with Multi-Gate Mixture of Experts
abstract: This paper introduces DeepUnifiedMom, a deep learning framework that enhances portfolio management through multi-task learning and a multi-gate mixture of experts architecture. It creates unified momentum portfolios by incorporating time-series momentum dynamics across multiple time frames, addressing limitations of traditional strategies. Comprehensive backtesting across equity indexes, fixed income, foreign exchange, and commodities shows consistent outperformance of benchmarks, even after transaction costs. The framework effectively captures a full spectrum of momentum opportunities, improving risk-adjusted returns and offering a valuable tool for practitioners in complex portfolio management.

title: PEN: Prediction-Explanation Network to Forecast Stock Price Movement with Better Explainability
abstract: This paper introduces the Prediction-Explanation Network (PEN), a framework designed to enhance both accuracy and explainability in stock price movement prediction. PEN jointly models text streams (e.g., financial news, social media) and price streams using a shared representation learning module that identifies salient texts correlated with price changes. It employs a variational autoencoder variant to handle stochastic factors and generates predictions while highlighting key explanatory texts. Experiments on real-world datasets show PEN outperforms state-of-the-art baselines in accuracy and significantly improves explainability over attention mechanisms.

title: Learning to Generate Explainable Stock Predictions using Self-Reflective Large Language Models
abstract: This paper introduces the Summarize-Explain-Predict (SEP) framework to address the challenge of generating explainable stock predictions using large language models (LLMs). Traditional deep learning models lack explainability, while LLMs struggle with weighing chaotic social texts' varying impacts on stock prices and generating verbal explanations. The SEP framework employs a self-reflective agent and Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) to autonomously teach an LLM to generate predictions and explanations. It summarizes input texts, uses self-reflection to learn from past movements, and fine-tunes the model with self-generated samples, eliminating the need for human annotation. Experimental results show superior prediction accuracy and Matthews correlation coefficient compared to traditional and LLM methods, with additional validation on portfolio construction tasks.

title: Minute-by-Minute: Financial Markets’ Reaction to the 2020 U.S. Election
abstract: This study analyzes the immediate impact of the 2020 U.S. presidential election on financial markets using minutely prediction market data from PredictIt. By examining the relationship between the Democratic presidency probability and various financial indicators—including currency pairs, bond prices, stock index futures, and volatility measures—the authors identify strong correlations consistent with 'risk-on' investor behavior. The market reaction is decomposed into uncertainty reduction and partisan outcome components, revealing distinct sensitivities across asset classes. Additionally, the analysis contrasts presidential and Senate election effects, highlighting bond markets' particular responsiveness to unified Democratic control scenarios.

title: From Deep Learning to LLMs: A survey of AI in Quantitative Investment
abstract: This survey explores the evolution of artificial intelligence in quantitative investment, focusing on alpha strategies as a representative example. It examines the progression from traditional statistical models with human-crafted features to deep learning approaches that enable scalable modeling across the entire investment pipeline. The paper highlights the emerging role of large language models (LLMs) in extending AI beyond prediction, empowering autonomous agents to process unstructured data, generate alphas, and support self-iterative workflows. The survey provides a comprehensive review of DL and LLM applications, discussing their respective advantages, challenges, and potential for paradigm shifts in quantitative finance.

title: Dynamic Datasets and Market Environments for Financial Reinforcement Learning
abstract: This paper introduces FinRL-Meta, an open-source library designed to address challenges in financial reinforcement learning (FinRL) by providing dynamic, high-quality market environments. It follows a DataOps paradigm to automatically curate and process real-world financial data into gym-style environments, mitigating issues like low signal-to-noise ratio, survivorship bias, and overfitting. The library includes benchmarks, educational demos, and cloud-based visualization tools to support reproducible research and community-driven development in FinRL applications.

title: PATHFORMER: MULTI-SCALE TRANSFORMERS WITH ADAPTIVE PATHWAYS FOR TIME SERIES FORECASTING
abstract: Pathformer is a novel multi-scale Transformer architecture for time series forecasting that integrates temporal resolution and temporal distance perspectives. It employs multi-scale division to create patches of varying sizes, then performs dual attention (inter-patch and intra-patch) to capture both global correlations and local details. The model features adaptive pathways with a multi-scale router that dynamically selects appropriate patch sizes and attention mechanisms based on input temporal dynamics, enhanced by trend and seasonality decomposition. Extensive experiments on eleven real-world datasets demonstrate state-of-the-art performance and strong generalization capabilities in transfer learning scenarios.

title: Fast ES-RNN: A GPU Implementation of the ES-RNN Algorithm
abstract: This paper presents a GPU-accelerated implementation of the ES-RNN algorithm, a hybrid model combining exponential smoothing and recurrent neural networks that won the M4 forecasting competition. By vectorizing the original C++ code and porting it to PyTorch, the authors achieve up to 322x training speedup on GPUs while maintaining similar forecasting accuracy. The implementation enhances accessibility through Python and enables easier generalization to diverse time-series applications, supporting broader adoption of hybrid forecasting models.

title: StockEmotions: Discover Investor Emotions for Financial Sentiment Analysis and Multivariate Time Series
abstract: This paper introduces StockEmotions, a novel dataset for detecting investor emotions in financial markets. The dataset contains 10,000 English comments from StockTwits annotated with 12 fine-grained emotion classes based on behavioral finance principles. Unlike existing financial sentiment datasets, StockEmotions provides granular features including investor sentiment classes, emotions, emojis, and time series data. Experimental results show that DistilBERT achieves the best performance for financial sentiment/emotion classification tasks, while a Temporal Attention LSTM model combining price index, text, and emotion features outperforms single-feature approaches in multivariate time series forecasting.

title: R&D-Agent-Quant: A Multi-Agent Framework for Data-Centric Factors and Model Joint Optimization
abstract: This paper introduces RD-Agent(Q), a data-centric multi-agent framework designed to automate quantitative strategy development by jointly optimizing factors and models. It addresses challenges of high dimensionality, non-stationarity, and fragmented workflows in financial markets. The framework decomposes the process into Research and Development stages, using dynamic prompts, hypothesis generation, and a code-generation agent (Co-STEER) for implementation. Backtesting and a multi-armed bandit scheduler enable iterative feedback. Empirical results show up to 2× higher annualized returns with 70% fewer factors compared to benchmarks, outperforming state-of-the-art deep time-series models.

title: UnetTSF: A Better Performance Linear Complexity Time Series Prediction Model
abstract: This paper introduces UnetTSF, a U-Net-based time series prediction model with linear complexity, addressing the high computational demands of Transformer-based models. It utilizes a Feature Pyramid Network (FPN) technique to extract multi-level features from time series data, replacing traditional trend-seasonal decomposition. The model integrates a fusion structure tailored for time series, enhancing feature utilization. Evaluated on eight open-source datasets, UnetTSF outperforms the linear baseline DLinear in 31 out of 32 tests, reducing MSE by 10.1% and MAE by 9.1% on average, and also shows competitive results against the complex PatchTST model.

title: The Structure of Financial Equity Research Reports – Identification of the Most Frequently Asked Questions in Financial Analyst Reports to Automate Equity Research Using Llama 3 and GPT-4
abstract: This study analyzes financial equity research reports (ERRs) by categorizing their content into question archetypes to assess automation potential. Through manual sentence-by-sentence analysis of 72 ERRs, 169 unique question types were identified from 4,940 sentences. The research evaluates whether answers to these questions can be extracted from corporate reports using large language models (LLMs) like Llama-3-70B and GPT-4-turbo. Results show that 78.7% of questions are automatable, with 48.2% text-extractable and 30.5% database-extractable, while only 21.3% require human judgment. The findings indicate that LLMs can automate approximately 80% of ERR content, enhancing efficiency and quality in financial analysis.

title: Reinforcement Learning in High-frequency Market Making
abstract: This paper provides a theoretical analysis of reinforcement learning (RL) in high-frequency market making, bridging modern RL theory with continuous-time financial models. It investigates the impact of sampling frequency (time increment Δ) on RL performance, revealing a trade-off: smaller Δ reduces error but increases computational complexity. The study extends to a two-player general-sum game framework, proving convergence of Nash equilibrium to continuous-time equilibrium as Δ approaches zero using Nash Q-learning. The findings are applicable to various high-frequency financial decision problems and are supported by Monte Carlo simulations.

title: AlphaQCM: Alpha Discovery in Finance with Distributional Reinforcement Learning
abstract: This paper introduces AlphaQCM, a novel distributional reinforcement learning method for discovering synergistic formulaic alphas in finance. It frames alpha discovery as a non-stationary, reward-sparse Markov decision process. AlphaQCM learns Q functions and quantiles via neural networks, then applies quantiled conditional moments to estimate unbiased variance, which guides exploration. Empirical results on real-world datasets show AlphaQCM outperforms competitors, especially with large stock datasets, achieving Information Coefficient values up to 9.55%.

title: Optimizing Time Series Forecasting: A Comparative Study of Adam and Nesterov Accelerated Gradient on LSTM and GRU Networks Using Stock Market Data
abstract: This paper compares the effectiveness of Adam and Nesterov Accelerated Gradient (NAG) optimization techniques on LSTM and GRU neural networks for stock market time-series forecasting. Using Apple Inc. closing price data from the past decade, models were trained and evaluated based on RMSE and convergence speed. Results show that GRU models optimized with Adam achieved the lowest RMSE, outperforming other combinations in accuracy and efficiency. GRU models generally surpassed LSTM models, and Adam outperformed NAG across both architectures, suggesting GRU with Adam is optimal for practical stock price prediction.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning for Cryptocurrency Trading: Practical Approach to Address Backtest Overfitting
abstract: This paper addresses the challenge of backtest overfitting in cryptocurrency trading using deep reinforcement learning. It formulates overfitting detection as a hypothesis test, trains DRL agents, estimates overfitting probability, and rejects overfitted agents to improve trading performance. Evaluated on 10 cryptocurrencies during a volatile testing period with two market crashes, the method shows that less overfitted agents achieve higher returns than overfitted agents, an equal weight strategy, and the S&P DBM Index, demonstrating potential for real-market deployment.

title: TimeXer: Empowering Transformers for Time Series Forecasting with Exogenous Variables
abstract: This paper introduces TimeXer, a novel framework that enhances Transformer architectures for time series forecasting with exogenous variables. Unlike traditional multivariate or univariate approaches, TimeXer specifically addresses the practical challenge of incorporating external information to improve endogenous variable prediction. The method employs a carefully designed embedding layer with patch-wise self-attention for temporal dependencies and variate-wise cross-attention to reconcile endogenous and exogenous information. A global endogenous variate token effectively bridges external series with temporal patches. Experimental results demonstrate state-of-the-art performance across twelve real-world forecasting benchmarks, showing significant improvements in accuracy when utilizing exogenous variables.

title: HybridRAG: Integrating Knowledge Graphs and Vector Retrieval Augmented Generation for Efficient Information Extraction
abstract: This paper introduces HybridRAG, a novel approach combining Knowledge Graph-based RAG (GraphRAG) and vector database-based RAG (VectorRAG) to enhance information extraction from financial documents. The method addresses challenges in processing unstructured financial text like earnings call transcripts, which contain domain-specific terminology and complex formats. Experiments on financial Q&A datasets demonstrate that HybridRAG outperforms both individual approaches in retrieval accuracy and answer generation quality. The technique shows particular effectiveness in financial applications but has broader applicability across domains requiring precise information extraction from unstructured text.

title: A Scalable Gradient-Based Optimization Framework for Sparse Minimum-Variance Portfolio Selection
abstract: This paper introduces a computationally efficient gradient-based optimization framework for sparse minimum-variance portfolio selection. The method addresses the NP-hard combinatorial problem of selecting at most k assets from a universe of p assets while minimizing portfolio variance. By transforming the discrete selection problem into a constrained continuous optimization via Boolean relaxation, the approach eliminates combinatorial complexity. The algorithm employs a tunable parameter that transitions the auxiliary objective from convex to concave, enabling stable initialization and controlled convergence to sparse binary solutions. Experimental results demonstrate that the method matches commercial solvers in asset selection for most instances while achieving significant computational speedups.

title: Tactical Asset Allocation with Macroeconomic Regime Detection
abstract: This paper introduces a novel tactical asset allocation framework that incorporates macroeconomic regime modeling using machine learning techniques. The approach utilizes a modified k-means algorithm to classify economic regimes from the FRED-MD macroeconomic dataset, forecasts future regime distributions, and integrates these predictions with historical asset performance to optimize portfolio allocations. The method outperforms traditional benchmarks including equal-weight, buy-and-hold, and random regime models, demonstrating significant improvements in portfolio performance through data-driven regime detection tailored for forecasting uncertainty.

abstract: This paper introduces a return-weighted loss function to enhance AI-driven stock selection by prioritizing high-growth opportunities. Using only publicly available stock data and technical indicators, the authors develop a CNN-based trading system that integrates categorical sector embeddings. The model achieves significant annual returns (61.73% from 2019-2024 and 37.61% from 2005-2010) with strong Sharpe Ratios, demonstrating superiority over traditional loss functions through rigorous performance metrics and statistical analysis.

abstract: MSGNet is a deep learning model designed to address the challenge of capturing varying inter-series correlations across different time scales in multivariate time series forecasting. It uses frequency domain analysis to decompose time series into distinct scales and employs adaptive graph convolution to learn diverse inter-series dependencies per scale, alongside a self-attention mechanism for intra-series patterns. Extensive experiments demonstrate its superior performance and generalization capabilities, even on out-of-distribution data.

abstract: This paper introduces LSR-IGRU, a novel model for stock trend prediction that integrates long and short-term stock relationships with an improved Gated Recurrent Unit (GRU) architecture. It constructs long-term relationships using secondary industry information and short-term relationships via overnight price correlations. The enhanced GRU input effectively combines temporal and relational data, improving prediction accuracy. Extensive experiments on Chinese and U.S. stock datasets demonstrate superior performance over state-of-the-art baselines, and real-world application in algorithmic trading shows higher cumulative portfolio returns.

abstract: This paper introduces Alpha-GPT, a novel interactive alpha mining system that leverages large language models to bridge human expertise and algorithmic search in quantitative investment. Traditional alpha mining methods face limitations in translating quant researchers' ideas into effective trading signals and interpreting algorithmically generated factors. Alpha-GPT employs prompt engineering to interpret natural language trading ideas, generate formulaic alphas, summarize results understandably, and iteratively refine searches based on user feedback. The system demonstrates improved efficiency and effectiveness in alpha discovery through human-AI collaboration.

title: REVISITING ATTENTION FOR MULTIVARIATE TIME SERIES FORECASTING
abstract: This paper investigates the optimality of conventional attention mechanisms in Transformers for Multivariate Time-Series Forecasting (MTSF). It introduces Frequency Spectrum attention (FSatten), which uses Fourier transform for embedding and Multi-head Spectrum Scaling (MSS) to replace linear projections of Query and Key, enabling better capture of periodic dependencies. Additionally, Scaled Orthogonal attention (SOatten) is proposed with orthogonal embedding and Head-Coupling Convolution (HCC) for broader dependency learning. Experiments on six benchmarks show FSatten and SOatten outperform state-of-the-art methods by 8.1% and 21.8% in MSE, respectively, demonstrating their effectiveness without architectural changes.

title: Curriculum Learning and Imitation Learning for Model-free Control on Financial Time-series
abstract: This paper explores curriculum learning (CL) and imitation learning (IL) for model-free reinforcement learning control tasks on financial time-series data, which are highly stochastic and noise-prone. CL is implemented via data augmentation to progressively expose the model to harder data, while IL uses policy distillation from an oracle. Empirical results show that CL significantly improves out-sample performance across multiple algorithms and datasets, even when hyperparameters are tuned for baselines. In contrast, IL requires cautious application due to mixed outcomes. The study bridges robotics-inspired learning paradigms with financial control, offering novel insights for signal optimization in limited-data environments.

title: StockMixer: A Simple Yet Strong MLP-Based Architecture for Stock Price Forecasting
abstract: StockMixer is a novel MLP-based architecture designed for stock price forecasting, addressing challenges in modeling indicator, temporal, and stock correlations. Unlike complex hybrid models prone to overfitting and optimization difficulties, StockMixer uses three mixing blocks: indicator mixing, patch-based multi-scale time mixing, and market-aware stock mixing. It explicitly captures stock-to-market and market-to-stock influences, improving robustness and predictive accuracy. Experiments on NASDAQ, NYSE, and S&P500 benchmarks show StockMixer outperforms state-of-the-art methods with reduced computational costs, offering a lightweight yet effective solution for quantitative investment.

abstract: This paper introduces Stockformer, a model integrating wavelet transformation and multitask self-attention networks to enhance stock selection in the complex Chinese market. It decomposes returns into high and low frequencies via discrete wavelet transform to capture both long-term trends and short-term fluctuations. The model employs a dual-frequency spatiotemporal encoder with graph embedding to analyze temporal and spatial relationships among stocks. Using multitask learning, it simultaneously predicts returns and directional trends. Experimental results show superior performance over existing methods, with high stability across various market conditions, especially during downturns and volatility.

title: LOB-Bench: Benchmarking Generative AI for Finance – an Application to Limit Order Book Data
abstract: LOB-Bench is a Python-based benchmark designed to evaluate the realism and quality of generative models for limit order book (LOB) data in the LOBSTER format. It measures distributional differences between generated and real data using conditional and unconditional statistics, including LOB-specific metrics like spread, order imbalance, and market impact functions. The framework supports multivariate statistical evaluation and includes discriminator network scores. Testing on autoregressive models, GANs, and parametric approaches shows that autoregressive GenAI outperforms traditional methods. The benchmark aims to standardize evaluation, foster model development, and is extensible to other high-dimensional time-series domains.

abstract: This paper introduces Style Miner, a reinforcement learning approach for extracting style factors in high-dimensional time series that balance high explanatory power and temporal stability. A Lagrangian heuristic adaptively balances these objectives. Experiments on financial datasets demonstrate that Style Miner outperforms existing learning-based methods and achieves a 10% relative gain in R-squared explanatory power compared to expert-designed factors.

abstract: This paper introduces an unsupervised machine learning method for contextual anomaly detection to support market surveillance in identifying potential insider trading. The approach uses principal component analysis and autoencoders for dimensionality reduction, analyzing trading positions of investors around price-sensitive events. abstract: This paper introduces a Dynamic Grid-based Trading (DGT) strategy for the cryptocurrency market, improving upon traditional grid trading. The authors first mathematically prove that the expected value of conventional grid trading is zero under certain assumptions. The DGT strategy dynamically adjusts grid levels to capitalize on market volatility, outperforming standard methods. abstract: This paper introduces FININ (Financial Interconnected News Influence Network), a novel model for financial market prediction that captures interactions among news items and their links to market prices. FININ integrates multi-modal data from market indices and news articles, addressing the complexity of news diffusion and influence. Evaluated on S&P 500 and NASDAQ 100 data over 15 years with 2.7 million news articles, it outperforms state-of-the-art methods, improving daily Sharpe ratios by 0.429 and 0.341 respectively. The model provides insights into delayed market pricing, long memory effects of news, and limitations of sentiment analysis.

title: Quantum Reinforcement Learning Trading Agent for Sector Rotation in the Taiwan Stock Market
abstract: This paper introduces a hybrid quantum-classical reinforcement learning framework for sector rotation in the Taiwan stock market, utilizing Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) with both classical (LSTM, Transformer) and quantum-enhanced (QNN, QRWKV, QASA) models. An automated feature engineering pipeline ensures consistent input from capital share data. Empirical backtesting reveals that quantum models achieve higher training rewards but underperform classical models in real-world metrics like cumulative return and Sharpe ratio, highlighting a mismatch between proxy rewards and true investment objectives. The study discusses challenges such as optimization instability in Noisy Intermediate-Scale Quantum (NISQ) constraints and proposes improvements like reward shaping and regularization.

title: KAN: Kolmogorov–Arnold Networks
abstract: This paper introduces Kolmogorov-Arnold Networks (KANs) as an alternative to Multi-Layer Perceptrons (MLPs). Unlike MLPs with fixed node activations, KANs place learnable activation functions on edges, parameterized as splines, eliminating linear weights entirely. KANs demonstrate superior accuracy and interpretability, achieving comparable or better performance with smaller architectures in data fitting and PDE solving. They exhibit faster neural scaling laws and can be visualized intuitively, aiding scientific discovery in mathematics and physics. KANs combine the strengths of splines and MLPs, effectively learning compositional structures and optimizing univariate functions, making them promising for enhancing deep learning models.

abstract: This paper provides a theoretical comparison of momentum (MOM) and moving average (MA) trend-following rules, addressing the lack of theoretical results in this area. The authors demonstrate that while MOM and MA rules exhibit high similarity, particularly with stronger trends, MA rules show superior robustness in forecasting future price direction accuracy. A hypothesis about uncertain market dynamics with randomly changing autoregressive parameters is introduced, explaining empirical observations such as the better performance of MA rules. Theoretical results are supported by numerical illustrations and practical implications for trading strategy design.

abstract: This paper proposes ML-GAT, a multilevel graph attention network for stock market trend prediction. It addresses limitations of existing methods by integrating multiple information sources including historical prices, news data, and stock relationships. The model uses BERT for text feature extraction and a novel attention mechanism to selectively aggregate information from different relation types. Experiments on S&P 500 and CSI 300 indices show significant improvements over benchmark models, with F1-score and accuracy increasing by 11.82% and 12.6% respectively, while also providing interpretable stock relationships.

title: Advancing Financial Engineering with Foundation Models: Progress, Applications, and Challenges
abstract: This survey explores the emergence of Financial Foundation Models (FFMs), which are large-scale pre-trained models tailored for financial applications. It categorizes FFMs into three modalities: Financial Language Foundation Models (FinLFMs) for text-based tasks, Financial Time-Series Foundation Models (FinTSFMs) for sequential data analysis, and Financial Visual-Language Foundation Models (FinVLFMs) for multimodal understanding. The paper reviews their architectures, training methods, datasets, and real-world uses, while addressing challenges like data scarcity, algorithmic scalability, and infrastructure limitations. It aims to serve as a comprehensive reference and roadmap for future innovation in financial AI.

title: Machine Learning from a “Universe” of Signals: The Role of Feature Engineering
abstract: This paper examines real-time machine learning investment strategies using a universe of over 18,000 fundamental signals accessible to investors. While strategies based on boosted regression trees and neural networks generate economically meaningful out-of-sample returns (0.95% per month with Sharpe ratio 1.02 for equal-weighted portfolios), their performance is significantly weaker than prior studies using curated signal sets. Simple recursive ranking of signal performance outperforms machine learning approaches. The results highlight the critical importance of feature engineering and inductive biases in enhancing machine learning strategy performance, demonstrating that human expertise in predictor selection substantially impacts economic outcomes.

title: Real-Time Stock Market Forecasting using Ensemble Deep Learning and Rainbow DQN
abstract: This paper addresses the challenge of accurate and lasting stock market prediction by proposing an ensemble approach combining Rainbow DQN, LSTM, and GRU for real-time forecasting and buy/sell signal generation. The methods are rigorously evaluated for overfitting and performance using accuracy and return on investment metrics, with validation through technical indicators like MACD and RSI. Testing on NIFTY50, Microsoft, and Google with 1-minute interval real-time data demonstrates the effectiveness of the ensemble in handling market uncertainty and improving decision-making for traders.

title: Deep Learning and NLP in Cryptocurrency Forecasting: Integrating Financial, Blockchain, and Social Media Data
abstract: This paper introduces novel machine learning and natural language processing approaches for forecasting cryptocurrency prices, focusing on Bitcoin and Ethereum. It analyzes news and social media content from Twitter and Reddit to assess public sentiment's impact, utilizing the BART MNLI zero-shot classification model to detect bullish and bearish trends. The study compares pre-trained and fine-tuned deep learning NLP models against traditional dictionary-based methods and adopts local extrema as predictive targets to reduce trading frequency and volatility. Results show that integrating textual data improves forecasting accuracy, profitability, and Sharpe ratio, with code made publicly available.

title: Automate Strategy Finding with LLM in Quant Investment
abstract: This paper introduces a novel framework for quantitative stock investment that leverages Large Language Models (LLMs) and multi-agent architectures to address instability and uncertainty in deep learning-based financial trading. The framework integrates LLMs to generate diversified alphas from multimodal financial data, including numerical data, research papers, and visual charts. It employs ensemble learning to create a pool of trading agents with varying risk preferences and uses a dynamic weight-gating mechanism to adaptively select and weight agents based on real-time market conditions. Extensive experiments on Chinese stock markets demonstrate superior performance over state-of-the-art baselines across multiple financial metrics, highlighting the efficacy of combining LLM-generated alphas with multi-agent evaluation for enhanced trading stability and returns.

title: JAX-LOB: A GPU-Accelerated limit order book simulator to unlock large scale reinforcement learning for trading
abstract: This paper introduces JAX-LOB, the first GPU-accelerated limit order book simulator designed for large-scale parallel processing of thousands of order books. The simulator leverages JAX's capabilities for just-in-time compilation and automatic vectorization to achieve significantly reduced per-message processing times while maintaining realistic LOB mechanisms. The implementation enables efficient training of reinforcement learning agents by eliminating GPU-CPU communication bottlenecks. As a demonstration, the authors integrate JAX-LOB with JAX-native RL frameworks to solve optimal execution problems, achieving a 7x speedup compared to CPU-based simulators during RL training.

title: LLM Knows Geometry Better than Algebra: Numerical Understanding of LLM-Based Agents in A Trading Arena
abstract: This paper introduces the Agent Trading Arena, a virtual numerical game that evaluates large language models' (LLMs) ability to generalize mathematical principles in a zero-sum stock market environment. Unlike static benchmarks, this dynamic simulation forces LLM-based agents to adapt to evolving market conditions through trading decisions based on historical prices. Experiments reveal that LLMs struggle with textual numerical data, focusing on absolute values rather than relational patterns, but perform significantly better with visualized numerical data (scatter plots, line charts). The reflection module further enhances performance with visual representations, demonstrating that LLMs exhibit stronger geometric reasoning than algebraic reasoning in financial contexts.

title: FinTSBridge: A New Evaluation Suite for Real-world Financial Prediction with Advanced Time Series Models
abstract: This paper introduces FinTSBridge, a comprehensive evaluation framework that bridges advanced time series forecasting models with real-world financial applications. The work addresses the gap between theoretical time series models and practical financial asset pricing by constructing three financial datasets (global stock indices, high-frequency options, and Bitcoin futures-spot data), evaluating over ten state-of-the-art forecasting models, and developing novel correlation-aware metrics (msIC and msIR) to complement traditional error metrics. The framework includes financial-specific tasks such as portfolio optimization and trading strategies to assess practical performance and economic utility in complex market environments.

title: Temporal Representation Learning for Stock Similarities and Its Applications in Investment Management
abstract: This paper introduces SimStock, a novel temporal self-supervised learning framework that combines SSL with temporal domain generalization to learn robust representations of financial time series data. The method addresses challenges in identifying similar stocks due to non-stationary markets and ambiguous conventional classifications. Through extensive experiments on four real-world datasets with thousands of stocks, SimStock demonstrates superior performance in finding similar stocks compared to existing methods. The framework's practical utility is validated through applications in pairs trading, index tracking, and portfolio optimization, showing enhanced investment decision-making and risk management capabilities.

title: Coupling Macro-Sector-Micro Financial Indicators for Learning Stock Representations with Less Uncertainty
abstract: This paper addresses the challenge of stock movement prediction by mitigating uncertainty from both data and modeling perspectives. The authors propose a copula-based contrastive predictive coding (Co-CPC) method to learn better stock representations. Co-CPC models dependencies between stock sectors and heterogeneous macroeconomic variables with varying time intervals, scales, and distributions. By incorporating macro-sector context, stock representations are learned through self-supervised learning for downstream prediction tasks. Extensive experiments on two stock datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach in reducing uncertainty and improving generalization.

title: TLOB: A Novel Transformer Model with Dual Attention for Stock Price Trend Prediction with Limit Order Book Data
abstract: This paper introduces TLOB, a transformer-based model with dual attention mechanism for stock price trend prediction using limit order book data. The model addresses limitations of existing approaches by capturing both spatial and temporal dependencies in LOB data, enabling adaptive focus on market microstructure. The authors also propose a new labeling method that eliminates horizon bias and evaluate their approach on the FI-2010 benchmark, achieving state-of-the-art performance with a 3.7% average F1-score improvement. The study demonstrates declining predictability over time and examines the impact of transaction costs on trend classification performance.

title: AlphaAgent: LLM-Driven Alpha Mining with Regularized Exploration to Counteract Alpha Decay
abstract: AlphaAgent is an autonomous framework that integrates large language models with regularization techniques to address alpha decay in quantitative investment. The system employs three key mechanisms: originality enforcement through AST-based similarity measures, hypothesis-factor alignment via LLM semantic consistency evaluation, and complexity control through structural constraints. These mechanisms guide alpha generation to balance originality, financial rationale, and market adaptability. Extensive evaluations demonstrate AlphaAgent's effectiveness in mitigating alpha decay, achieving significant excess returns in both Chinese CSI 500 and U.S. S&P 500 markets while maintaining robust performance across different market regimes.

abstract: This study introduces novel concepts in limit order book (LOB) analysis, focusing on the total market order book bid–ask spread (TMOBBAS) and global mid-price (GMP). Using high-frequency data from stocks like Amazon, Apple, and Google, the research examines these metrics through tail behavior analysis, log-return dynamics, and risk–return evaluation. Findings reveal insights into market liquidity, volatility, and efficiency under varying conditions, offering strategic value for traders, risk managers, and policymakers in navigating financial market complexities.

title: Developing A Multi-Agent and Self-Adaptive Framework with Deep Reinforcement Learning for Dynamic Portfolio Risk Management
abstract: This paper introduces MASA, a multi-agent and self-adaptive framework using deep reinforcement learning for dynamic portfolio risk management. It addresses the limitation of traditional RL agents that focus on maximizing returns while neglecting risks in turbulent markets. MASA employs two cooperating agents: one optimizes portfolio returns using the TD3 algorithm, and another minimizes risks via constraint solvers. A market observer agent provides trend feedback to enhance adaptability. Empirical results on CSI 300, DJIA, and S&P 500 datasets over 10 years demonstrate superior performance against existing RL approaches, highlighting balanced risk-return trade-offs and resilience in volatile conditions.

title: A Modified CTGAN-Plus-Features Based Method for Optimal Asset Allocation
abstract: This paper introduces a novel portfolio optimization approach combining synthetic data generation via a modified CTGAN algorithm with a CVaR constraint. The method incorporates contextual information from the U.S. Treasury yield curve to generate synthetic return scenarios, which are used in an asset allocation framework across ten asset classes. Evaluated over a 14.5-year period (2008-2022), the approach demonstrates superior out-of-sample performance compared to equal-weight strategies and historical data-only optimizations, effectively capturing key data characteristics and improving portfolio outcomes.

title: Large Language Models Are Zero-Shot Time Series Forecasters
abstract: This paper demonstrates that large language models (LLMs) like GPT-3 and LLaMA-2 can perform zero-shot time series forecasting by encoding time series as strings of numerical digits and treating forecasting as next-token prediction. The proposed method, LLMTIME, involves effective tokenization of time series data and conversion of discrete token distributions into continuous densities. LLMs achieve performance comparable to or better than specialized time series models, benefiting from their ability to represent multimodal distributions, handle missing data without imputation, incorporate textual side information, and provide explanations. Performance scales with model size, though alignment interventions like RLHF can impair calibration, as seen with GPT-4.

title: An End-to-End Structure with Novel Position Mechanism and Improved EMD for Stock Forecasting
abstract: This paper introduces ACEFormer, an end-to-end solution for stock trend prediction that addresses challenges like high noise and irregular time intervals in financial data. It integrates an improved Empirical Mode Decomposition (ACEEMD) for noise reduction, a time-aware mechanism to enhance positional information, and an attention-based model to incorporate both individual stock and market-wide data. Evaluated on NASDAQ and SPY datasets over ten years, ACEFormer outperforms state-of-the-art baselines, demonstrating superior forecasting accuracy and robustness in handling non-linear, volatile stock time series.

Each factor is precisely defined with mathematical formulas and calculation methodologies, incorporating time-series regression, weighted averages, and financial ratios. The model integrates both fundamental data (e.g., market capitalization, financial statements) and market data (e.g., returns, turnover) to capture risk and return drivers. It serves as a foundational framework for quantitative risk management and portfolio construction in equity markets.

title: Diffusion Factor Models: Generating High-Dimensional Returns with Factor Structure
abstract: This paper introduces a diffusion factor model that integrates latent factor structure into generative diffusion processes to address high-dimensional financial scenario simulation under data scarcity. By leveraging low-dimensional factor structures inherent in asset returns, the model decomposes the score function using time-varying orthogonal projections and incorporates this into neural network design. It provides non-asymptotic error bounds for score estimation and generated distribution, showing performance driven by intrinsic factor dimension rather than asset count, enabling viability for markets with thousands of assets. Empirical results demonstrate effectiveness in portfolio optimization and factor analysis.

title: Choosing Investment Managers
abstract: This study examines how relationships influence the selection of investment managers by plan sponsors. Using proprietary data from Relationship Science, the authors analyze 5,245 hiring decisions involving $1.1 trillion in assets. Investment managers connected to plan sponsors are 18% more likely to be hired than unconnected managers, an effect comparable to prior performance. However, these connections do not result in higher post-hiring returns, suggesting relationships facilitate asset gathering without generating commensurate financial benefits for plan sponsors. The research provides insights into agency costs and inefficiencies in institutional asset delegation.

abstract: This paper introduces FinVision, a multi-modal multi-agent system for financial trading that leverages specialized LLM-based agents to process diverse financial data, including textual news, candlestick charts, and trading signals. A key innovation is the reflection module, which analyzes historical trading outcomes to enhance future decision-making. The framework demonstrates improved performance over traditional deep learning and reinforcement learning methods, with ablation studies highlighting the critical role of visual reflection in boosting decision accuracy and interpretability.

abstract: This paper introduces GRAPHCNNPRED, a graph neural network-based convolutional neural network model designed for predicting stock market indices trends. The model processes diverse data sources, including primitive features, technical indicators, economic data, and global market indices, to extract meaningful patterns. It leverages graph structures to capture inter-market relationships and employs CNN layers for temporal feature extraction. The approach is validated on major indices such as S&P 500, NASDAQ, DJI, NYSE, and RUSSEL, demonstrating effectiveness in trend prediction through experimental results and trading simulations.

title: Internet sentiment exacerbates intraday overtrading, evidence from Guba
abstract: This study investigates how investor sentiment derived from social media posts on the Eastmoney 'Guba' forum influences intraday overtrading in the Chinese A-share market. Using high-frequency sentiment indices for CSI 300 and SZSE 500 constituents from 2018 to 2022, the analysis reveals a significant positive impact of sentiment on overtrading, with stronger effects among institutional investors and during bull markets. Individual investors in large-cap stocks are more affected than those in small- and mid-cap stocks, highlighting the role of sentiment in driving irrational trading behaviors.

abstract: This study proposes integrating large language model (LLM)-generated views into portfolio optimization using the Black-Litterman framework to address sensitivity issues in traditional mean-variance models. The method leverages LLMs to estimate expected stock returns from historical prices and company metadata, incorporating prediction variance as uncertainty. Backtesting from June 2024 to February 2025 with biweekly rebalancing shows varying predictive optimism and confidence stability across different LLMs (LLaMA-3.1-8B, Gemma-7B, Qwen-2-7B, GPT-4o-mini), impacting portfolio performance compared to S&P 500, equal-weighted, and traditional mean-variance baselines.

abstract: This paper introduces the use of Conditional Variational Auto-Encoder (CVAE) for forecasting daily stock volume time series, incorporating advanced information such as known future events like index rebalancing dates. The CVAE generates non-linear, out-of-sample forecasts that outperform traditional linear models in accuracy and correlation fit. It also enables scenario generation for improved interpretability. The methodology is applied to EURO STOXX 50 stocks, demonstrating effectiveness in both short and long-term forecasting tasks, with applications in financial derivatives pricing and empirical finance.

title: DiffsFormer: A Diffusion Transformer on Stock Factor Augmentation
abstract: This paper addresses data scarcity challenges in stock forecasting, characterized by low signal-to-noise ratio and data homogeneity, by proposing DiffsFormer—a diffusion model with transformer architecture for stock factor augmentation. Experiments on CSI300 and CSI800 datasets show relative improvements of 7.2% and 27.8% in annualized return ratio across eight machine learning models, demonstrating enhanced forecasting accuracy and robustness against overfitting.

abstract: This paper introduces the Multi-relational Dynamic Graph Neural Network (MDGNN) framework to address challenges in stock price prediction by capturing multifaceted and temporal influences. Traditional methods often overlook complex inter-stock relations and their evolution. MDGNN constructs discrete dynamic graphs with daily stock and relationship data, using multi-relational graph embedding for comprehensive representation. It employs Transformer architecture to encode temporal evolution of multiplex relations, enhancing prediction accuracy. Experiments on public datasets show MDGNN outperforms state-of-the-art methods in stock investment prediction.

abstract: This paper introduces a principled two-layer framework for autonomous domain knowledge acquisition in specialized fields like quantitative investment. The inner loop enables an agent to refine responses using its knowledge base, while the outer loop tests these responses in real-world scenarios to automatically enhance the knowledge base with new insights. Theoretical analysis demonstrates efficient convergence toward optimal behavior. The framework is instantiated as QuantAgent, an autonomous agent for mining trading signals, which empirically shows capability in uncovering viable financial signals and improving financial forecast accuracy.

It addresses limitations of traditional methods by analyzing spatial correlations and market microstructure relationships through dynamic correlation matrices and an attention-based autoencoder. Support levels are extracted via unsupervised clustering with DBSCAN. Evaluated on S&P 500 data, DeepSupp outperforms six baselines across six financial metrics, demonstrating state-of-the-art accuracy and sensitivity to market regimes, offering a scalable solution for technical analysis.

abstract: StockMixer introduces a novel MLP-based architecture for stock price forecasting, addressing the challenge of modeling indicator, temporal, and stock correlations in a simple yet effective manner. Experiments on NASDAQ, NYSE, and S&P500 datasets demonstrate superior performance over RNN, GNN, and other baselines in metrics like Information Coefficient and Sharpe Ratio, with significant average gains. abstract: This paper introduces a deep learning framework for optimizing Volume-Weighted Average Price (VWAP) execution in cryptocurrency markets, bypassing traditional volume curve prediction. abstract: This paper introduces RAG-MCP, a Retrieval-Augmented Generation framework designed to address prompt bloat and selection complexity when large language models (LLMs) interact with numerous external tools defined by the Model Context Protocol (MCP). Experiments demonstrate that RAG-MCP cuts prompt tokens by over 50% and more than triples tool selection accuracy (43.13% vs 13.62% baseline) on benchmark tasks, enabling scalable and accurate tool integration for LLMs.

abstract: This paper introduces a novel framework for stock selection using multi-source data fusion and decision-level fusion to enhance reliability and overcome limitations of single models. title: Disentangling Long-Short Term State Under Unknown Interventions for Online Time Series Forecasting
abstract: This paper addresses the challenge of online time series forecasting, where existing methods struggle to preserve long-term dependencies while adapting to short-term changes in sequentially arriving data. The authors propose a framework to disentangle long and short-term states, inspired by unknown interventions (e.g., abrupt policies in finance) that cause nonstationarity. They formalize a data generation process with interventions on short-term states and establish an identification theory for disentanglement. The Long Short-Term Disentanglement (LSTD) model uses encoders for each state type, incorporating smooth and interrupted dependency constraints to enhance separation. Experiments on benchmarks show LSTD outperforms state-of-the-art methods in real-world applications.

abstract: This paper introduces TFB, a comprehensive benchmarking framework for time series forecasting methods. abstract: This paper documents significant time series momentum across 58 liquid futures instruments including equity indices, currencies, commodities, and bonds. Returns show persistence for 1-12 months followed by partial reversal, consistent with behavioral theories of under-reaction and over-reaction. A diversified time series momentum portfolio delivers substantial abnormal returns with low exposure to standard factors and performs best during extreme markets. Analysis of CFTC data reveals speculators profit from these trends at hedgers' expense. The effect is driven by both spot price predictability and roll yield components.

title: FinReport: Explainable Stock Earnings Forecasting via News Factor Analyzing Model
abstract: FinReport is an automated system designed to assist ordinary investors by generating explainable stock earnings forecasts through news analysis. It integrates financial news and a multi-factor model, comprising three modules: news factorization (combining semantic understanding with stock factors), return forecasting (assessing news impact on market sentiment using the Fama-French model), and risk assessment (evaluating investment risk with EGARCH and VaR). The system outputs readable reports via a large language model, validated on real-world datasets for effectiveness and explainability, improving ROI and Sharpe Ratio.

title: Robust Market Making: To Quote, or not To Quote

Using adversarial reinforcement learning, two new agents are designed: one with a two-action space (quote or not quote) and another with a four-action space (bid-ask quotes, refuse, or single-sided quotes). Empirical evaluations in adversarial environments demonstrate that these flexible strategies improve returns and Sharpe ratios by mitigating risks such as price volatility and inventory imbalances, while meeting market quoting requirements effectively.

abstract: This paper introduces StockGPT, an autoregressive generative AI model trained on 70 million daily U.S. stock returns from 1926 to 2000. Tested on data from 2001 to 2023, a daily rebalanced long-short portfolio based on StockGPT predictions achieved an annual return of 119% and a Sharpe ratio of 6.5. The model subsumes traditional price-based strategies like momentum and reversals, demonstrating the potential of generative AI in automating and enhancing financial decision-making without manual factor crafting.

title: Are Language Models Actually Useful for Time Series Forecasting?
abstract: This paper investigates the utility of large language models (LLMs) in time series forecasting through ablation studies on three popular LLM-based methods. Findings indicate that removing or replacing the LLM component with a basic attention layer does not degrade—and often improves—forecasting performance. Pretrained LLMs show no advantage over models trained from scratch, fail to capture sequential dependencies, and offer no benefit in few-shot settings. Additionally, simpler encoders with patching and attention structures achieve comparable results, highlighting significant computational inefficiencies without performance gains.

abstract: This paper introduces the Augmented Disentanglement Distillation (ADD) framework to enhance stock trend forecasting by addressing feature entanglement in noisy raw data. The method employs a disentanglement structure to separate market and excess return information, preventing mutual interference. A dynamic self-distillation technique further removes implicit noise factors, and a novel data augmentation strategy leverages disentangled features to improve performance, especially for rare samples. Experiments on Chinese stock market data demonstrate significant improvements in forecasting accuracy and investment returns through backtesting.

title: Mining Intraday Risk Factor Collections via Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning based on Transferred Options
abstract: This paper introduces a Hierarchical Proximal Policy Optimization (HPPO) framework with Transferred Options (HPPO-TO) for automated generation and evaluation of high-frequency risk factors. Traditional manual and statistical methods often fail to capture nonlinear relationships or adapt to market dynamics. HPPO-TO uses a two-level policy: a high-level policy assigns weights to stock features, and a low-level policy applies mathematical operators to identify latent nonlinear factors. Transfer learning pre-trains the high-level policy on historical data and fine-tunes it with recent data, improving adaptability. The Pearson correlation with realized volatility serves as the reward. Experiments across U.S., Chinese, and Indian markets show a 25% excess return compared to baselines.

abstract: This study compares an AI analyst trained on corporate disclosures, industry trends, and macroeconomic indicators against human stock analysts in predicting 12-month stock returns. The AI outperforms most analysts overall, especially with transparent, voluminous data, while humans excel in areas requiring institutional knowledge, such as intangible assets and financial distress. The findings highlight how human analysts can adapt and improve by leveraging AI, particularly when alternative data and AI capabilities are integrated.

Grid trading involves placing buy and sell orders at predetermined intervals to capitalize on market movements while managing risk through position averaging. The system combines high-frequency trading with machine learning for financial time series forecasting to enhance performance. Results demonstrate reduced drawdown and improved robustness, confirming the effectiveness of the approach in handling the high volatility and unpredictability of currency markets.

abstract: This paper introduces CryptoPulse, a novel framework for short-term cryptocurrency price forecasting that addresses limitations of existing methods by incorporating three critical factors: macroeconomic fluctuations of major cryptocurrencies, market sentiment from news analysis, and technical indicators. The proposed dual-prediction mechanism separately forecasts prices based on macro conditions and cryptocurrency dynamics, then fuses them using a market sentiment-driven strategy. The model employs few-shot learning and consistency-based calibration for LLM-based sentiment analysis of cryptocurrency news. Extensive evaluations on a large-scale real-world dataset demonstrate state-of-the-art performance, outperforming ten comparison methods in next-day price prediction.

title: Non-stationary Transformers: Exploring the Stationarity in Time Series Forecasting
abstract: This paper addresses the challenge of using Transformers for time series forecasting on non-stationary real-world data, where performance degrades due to changing joint distributions. While stationarization improves predictability, it causes over-stationarization, making temporal attentions indistinguishable and reducing model capability. The proposed Non-stationary Transformers framework includes Series Stationarization for better predictability and De-stationary Attention to recover intrinsic non-stationarity. This approach significantly boosts mainstream Transformers, reducing MSE by up to 49.43% and achieving state-of-the-art results on six benchmarks.

title: Hidden Markov Models for Stock Market Prediction
abstract: This paper explores the use of Hidden Markov Models (HMMs) to predict stock market prices, addressing the challenges of market volatility and complexity. HMMs are statistical models that handle partially observable systems, making them suitable for modeling stock prices based on historical data. The model is trained and tested to predict closing prices using opening prices and previous day data, evaluated with Mean Average Prediction Error (MAPE) and a novel Directional Prediction Accuracy (DPA) metric. Results demonstrate the potential of HMMs in enhancing prediction accuracy for better investment decisions.

abstract: This paper introduces a deep reinforcement learning (RL) agent for market making using limit order book (LOB) data. The agent employs a neural network with convolutional filters and an attention mechanism (Attn-LOB) to extract features from high-dimensional, noisy LOB data. A novel continuous action space and hybrid reward function are designed to optimize bid and ask quotes, capturing spreads while managing inventory risks. Experiments demonstrate the agent's effectiveness in latency and interpretability, showing practical applicability in high-frequency trading environments without relying on strong market assumptions.

title: Evaluating Financial Relational Graphs: Interpretation Before Prediction
abstract: This paper addresses limitations in stock trend forecasting by introducing the SPNews dataset for S&P 500 stocks and a novel evaluation framework for financial relationship graphs. Traditional methods rely on predefined static graphs and evaluate graphs based on downstream task performance, which can obscure graph deficiencies. The proposed framework decouples graph evaluation from neural networks, assessing graphs by their ability to explain historical financial phenomena before model construction. Experiments show the method effectively differentiates between graphs and provides more interpretable results than traditional approaches.

abstract: This paper empirically investigates macroscopic properties of the US equity market using the CRSP Database, focusing on market capitalizations and returns. It identifies stylized facts such as the stability of the capital distribution curve, the maintenance of market diversity through stock entrances and exits, and clustering of relative volatility. abstract: This paper proposes a Temporal and Heterogeneous Graph Neural Network (THGNN) approach for financial time series prediction. THGNN dynamically generates company relation graphs from historical price data, uses a transformer encoder for temporal representations, and employs a heterogeneous graph attention network to optimize embeddings and predict price movements. abstract: This paper introduces LLMoE, a novel framework that integrates large language models (LLMs) as routers within a mixture-of-experts (MoE) architecture for stock trading. Traditional MoE models use static neural network routers that lack contextual understanding and ignore multimodal data. LLMoE leverages LLMs' reasoning capabilities to process both historical price data and news headlines, enabling dynamic expert selection based on market context. The framework categorizes experts into positive and negative market perspectives, improving prediction accuracy. Experiments on real-world stock datasets demonstrate superior performance compared to state-of-the-art MoE and deep learning approaches, with enhanced interpretability and adaptability to various trading tasks.

abstract: This paper introduces xLSTM, an extension of the Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) architecture designed to overcome its limitations in scalability and performance. When integrated into residual blocks and scaled to billions of parameters, xLSTM demonstrates competitive performance against state-of-the-art Transformers and State Space Models, addressing issues like storage revision, capacity limits, and lack of parallelizability.

It outperforms prior models in log-likelihood, computational efficiency, covariance estimation, risk forecasting (e.g., VaR), and portfolio optimization. UniTime addresses three key challenges: varying data characteristics across domains, domain confusion where models struggle to distinguish between different domains, and imbalanced convergence rates. The model features flexible architecture to handle diverse input/output lengths, uses natural language domain instructions for identification, and employs a Language-TS Transformer to align time series with language model representations. Masking techniques mitigate convergence imbalance issues. Extensive experiments demonstrate UniTime's state-of-the-art performance and strong zero-shot transfer capabilities across multiple domains.

They propose fine-tuning TimesFM through continual pre-training on a curated financial dataset containing 100 million time points across various instruments and granularities. The fine-tuned model demonstrates superior price prediction accuracy compared to the baseline. PGN uses a Historical Information Extraction layer and gated mechanisms to reduce propagation to O(1) complexity, enabling parallel computation and better long-term dependency capture. TimePro introduces a Mamba-based approach that constructs variate- and time-aware hyper-states, preserving fine-grained temporal features and adaptively selecting critical time points. Unlike prior methods relying on keyphrases or sentiment analysis, LLMFactor focuses on identifying directly relevant factors, providing clear explanations for temporal changes. The approach involves generating background knowledge via fill-in-the-blank prompts, discerning factors from news, and leveraging historical stock prices in textual format for prediction. abstract: This paper introduces an asymptotically unbiased and efficient estimator for the effective bid–ask spread using open, high, low, and close prices, addressing the downward bias in existing estimators caused by infrequent trading and discrete price observations. title: Causal Factor Investing: Can Factor Investing Become Scientific?
abstract: This Element critiques the factor investing literature for its reliance on associational claims rather than causal theories. Unlike previous methods that start from white Gaussian noise, ARMD uses deterministic sliding operations to generate intermediate states, eliminating uncertainty and leveraging valuable intermediate information. title: Intraday Arbitrage Between ETFs and Their Underlying Portfolios
abstract: This study examines the impact of ETF trading on underlying securities at intraday frequencies, using minute-by-minute data from 423 U.S. equity ETFs (2006–2015). abstract: This paper introduces a revised long short-term memory (LSTM) cell architecture optimized for high-frequency trading forecasting. Operating with a shallow topology and minimal look-back period, the cell is trained online to handle time irregularities in high-frequency data. abstract: This paper introduces ClusterLOB, a method for clustering individual market events in market-by-order (MBO) data using six time-dependent features and the K-means++ algorithm. It treats time series as cumulative sums of fine-grained increments governed by a novel spin-gas dynamical Ising model, motivating a parsimonious set of operators for abstract feature summarization. The framework allows users to incorporate inductive biases via customizable templates and generates large-scale predictive features through a hierarchical pipeline. Empirical validation on synthetic and real-world datasets demonstrates significant improvements in prediction accuracy, adaptability, and robustness across various models and scenarios.

The authors propose an end-to-end deep learning framework with comprehensive label imbalance adjustment methods to predict returns in the Chinese futures market. By leveraging rigorous preprocessing techniques and cost-sensitive learning approaches, the model effectively mitigates bias toward majority classes, enhancing prediction accuracy and robustness in fast-paced trading environments where misclassification can lead to substantial financial losses.

The proposed approach treats each order as an agent that communicates intended actions through a learnable multi-round protocol. Experiments on real-world market data demonstrate superior performance and improved coordination effectiveness compared to existing methods.

abstract: This paper introduces MASS (Multi-Agent Scaling Simulation), a novel framework for portfolio construction using large-scale multi-agent simulations. Unlike existing approaches limited to pure simulations or predefined workflows, MASS employs a reverse optimization process to dynamically optimize agent distribution end-to-end, enabling stable and continuous excess returns. The system demonstrates scaling laws where increasing the number of agents (up to 512) leads to superior market understanding and improved performance. Experiments on real asset data show a 3.83% increase in correlation with returns and superior excess returns compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Learning Universal Multi-level Market Irrationality Factors to Improve Stock Return Forecasting
abstract: This paper introduces UMI, a Universal Multi-level Market Irrationality factor model to enhance stock return forecasting by addressing irrational behaviors often overlooked in deep learning models. UMI learns factors from both stock and market levels: at the stock level, it estimates a rational price cointegrated with the actual price, using the discrepancy as an irrationality indicator; at the market level, it identifies anomalous synchronous fluctuations via self-supervised tasks like sub-market comparative learning and market synchronism prediction. abstract: This paper introduces minimal adaptations to the original transformer architecture to make it suitable for continuous-value time series forecasting, a sequence-to-sequence problem. It introduces a bi-level transparency framework that combines understanding of high-level trends and low-level properties of predicted trajectories. The authors develop TIMEVIEW, a transparent machine learning model for forecasting based on static features, accompanied by an interactive visualization tool. abstract: This paper introduces Fin-GAN, a novel approach using Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) for probabilistic forecasting and classification of financial time series. title: Does Peer-Reviewed Research Help Predict Stock Returns?
abstract: This paper compares the post-sample performance of peer-reviewed cross-sectional return predictors with data-mined benchmarks from 29,000 accounting ratios. Risk-based or equilibrium-model-supported predictors underperform, indicating peer review may mislabel mispricing as risk. Data mining replicates key features of academic research, including return decay patterns and thematic discoveries (e.g., investment, accruals) decades before publication. The study challenges the notion that economic theory enhances out-of-sample robustness relative to naive data mining.

abstract: This study presents an autonomous machine learning protocol for high-frequency trading stock price forecasting using a dual competitive feature importance mechanism and automated clustering via radial basis function neural networks. abstract: This paper challenges the conventional masked time series modeling approach that relies on capturing dependencies between patches using Transformers. The authors propose a patch-independent strategy for time series representation learning, arguing that embedding patches independently yields better results. The method includes a patch reconstruction task that autoencodes each patch without considering others, and uses a simple MLP architecture for independent patch embedding. Complementary contrastive learning is introduced to efficiently capture adjacent time series information. title: Valuing Stocks With Earnings
abstract: This paper addresses the excess volatility puzzle in stock prices by examining valuation ratios. It demonstrates that traditional earnings measures, such as GAAP earnings, have high transitory volatility, making price-earnings ratios uninformative. The authors propose using Street earnings, which exclude transitory items, as a more stable and informative fundamental measure. The Street price-earnings ratio is shown to be driven by future returns rather than earnings growth, reconciling the Campbell-Shiller decomposition with the excess volatility puzzle. Empirical results indicate that the Street PE has strong in- and out-of-sample predictive power for stock returns, outperforming other valuation ratios.

abstract: This paper introduces FactorGCL, a novel hypergraph-based factor model that enhances stock return prediction by supplementing human-designed prior factors with data-driven hidden factors. The model employs a cascading residual hypergraph architecture to capture high-order nonlinear relationships among stocks and factors, extracting hidden factors from residual information after removing prior factor influence. A temporal residual contrastive learning method is proposed to guide effective factor extraction by contrasting stock-specific residuals across different time periods. Experimental results on real market data demonstrate that FactorGCL outperforms state-of-the-art methods and successfully mines effective hidden factors for stock return prediction.

abstract: This paper introduces a machine learning approach for stock movement prediction, focusing on classifying whether a stock's price will rise or fall. The key innovation is the use of adversarial training to enhance the generalization of neural network models. Given that stock price features are stochastic and time-varying, standard training methods risk overfitting. The proposed method adds perturbations to simulate price variability, training the model to remain robust under intentional noise. Experiments on real-world stock datasets demonstrate a 3.11% average accuracy improvement over state-of-the-art methods, confirming the effectiveness of adversarial training in financial prediction tasks.

abstract: This paper introduces One-shot Entropy Minimization (EM), an unsupervised method for post-training large language models (LLMs) that requires only a single unlabeled data point and 10 optimization steps. EM minimizes token-level entropy to enhance model confidence and performance, achieving gains comparable to or exceeding those of reinforcement learning (RL) approaches that use thousands of labeled examples and carefully designed rewards. The state space comprises volatility-normalized daily returns, with actions being buying or selling, and rewards defined as cumulative profits. The strategy is trained and tested on both real and simulated price series, with performance compared against an S&P 500 index benchmark. The study focuses on trading E-mini S&P 500 continuous futures contracts and investigates how combining artificial data (generated via geometric Brownian motion and variance gamma processes) with actual price series can enhance real-market deployment. abstract: This paper introduces MacroHFT, a novel reinforcement learning framework for high-frequency trading in cryptocurrency markets. The method addresses limitations of existing RL approaches by incorporating market context through two phases: first training specialized sub-agents on market data decomposed by trend and volatility indicators with conditional adapters, then training a hyper-agent with memory mechanism to combine sub-agent decisions into a robust meta-policy. The approach demonstrates state-of-the-art performance on minute-level trading tasks across multiple cryptocurrency markets, effectively handling rapid market fluctuations and reducing overfitting issues.

title: Multi-period Learning for Financial Time Series Forecasting
abstract: This paper introduces the Multi-period Learning Framework (MLF) to enhance financial time series forecasting by addressing the limitations of single-period input models. Financial time series are influenced by multi-period factors, including short-term public opinions and long-term market trends. MLF incorporates three novel modules: Inter-period Redundancy Filtering to eliminate redundancy between periods, Learnable Weighted-average Integration for effective forecast combination, and Multi-period self-Adaptive Patching to mitigate period bias. Additionally, a Patch Squeeze module improves computational efficiency. The framework handles inputs of varying lengths, reducing training overhead and improving accuracy in real-world financial applications like fund sales forecasting.

The study identifies security and privacy risks at each stage and proposes mitigation strategies. Finally, it outlines future research directions and recommendations for secure and sustainable development within the evolving AI ecosystem.

title: Frequency Adaptive Normalization For Non-stationary Time Series Forecasting
abstract: This paper introduces Frequency Adaptive Normalization (FAN), a novel method to address non-stationarity in time series forecasting. Unlike prior reversible instance normalization techniques that rely on statistical measures like mean and variance to handle trends, FAN uses Fourier transforms to identify and adapt to both dynamic trends and seasonal patterns. It filters top frequency components for each input instance and employs an MLP to predict future non-stationary information, enabling accurate reconstruction of outputs. FAN is model-agnostic and tested on four forecasting backbones across eight benchmarks, showing significant improvements in MSE by 7.76% to 37.90%.

title: Quantifying the High-Frequency Trading "Arms Race"
abstract: This paper uses stock exchange message data to quantify latency arbitrage in high-frequency trading, revealing its frequency, speed, and economic impact. Unlike limit order book data, message data capture both successful and failed trade attempts, allowing direct observation of arbitrage races. Findings show races occur about once per minute per FTSE 100 stock, last 5-10 microseconds on average, and account for 20% of trading volume. The top six firms dominate race participation. Although individual races yield small profits, aggregate stakes are substantial, contributing to liquidity costs and imposing an estimated 0.5 basis point tax on trading, with global equity market impacts around $5 billion annually.
