title: Extracting Alpha from Financial Analyst Networks
abstract: This paper investigates a momentum trading strategy based on financial analyst coverage networks, where edge weights represent the number of analysts jointly covering pairs of firms. While prior research has examined the link between analyst coverage and stock price co-movement, this work systematically learns optimal signal combinations from jointly covered firms to exploit spillover effects. The proposed approach uses a graph attention network to aggregate individual firm features and signals from neighboring firms in a node-level forecasting task. The resulting portfolio achieves 29.44% annualized returns and a Sharpe ratio of 4.06, significantly outperforming market baselines and existing graph machine learning frameworks. The study demonstrates the effectiveness of graph machine learning for extracting actionable insights from analyst networks in financial applications.

title: StockAICloud: AI based Sustainable and Scalable Stock Price Prediction Framework using Serverless Cloud Computing
abstract: This paper introduces StockAICloud, an AI-based framework for stock price prediction leveraging serverless cloud computing for scalability and sustainability. The framework utilizes three deep learning models—LSTM, GRU, and CNN—to forecast open and close prices of HDFC Bank stock using historical Yahoo Finance data. Experimental results show LSTM achieved the highest performance (R²=0.9106). Deployments on server-based (Amazon EC2) and serverless (AWS Fargate) environments were compared, with serverless demonstrating superior scalability, handling up to 400 concurrent requests at 21.2 requests per minute. The integration of deep learning with serverless cloud services enables sustainable, real-time financial predictions.

title: Mamba Meets Financial Markets: A Graph-Mamba Approach for Stock Price Prediction
abstract: This paper introduces SAMBA, a novel framework for stock return prediction that combines the Mamba architecture with graph neural networks (GNNs) to address the computational limitations of transformer-based models. SAMBA utilizes a bidirectional Mamba block to capture long-term dependencies in historical price data with near-linear complexity and employs adaptive graph convolution to model interactions between daily stock features. Experimental results show that SAMBA outperforms state-of-the-art baselines in predictive accuracy while maintaining low computational costs, making it suitable for real-time trading applications.

title: Hierarchical Reinforced Trader (HRT): A Bi-Level Approach for Optimizing Stock Selection and Execution
abstract: This paper introduces the Hierarchical Reinforced Trader (HRT), a novel trading strategy using a bi-level Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning framework to address challenges like the curse of dimensionality, inertia in trading actions, and insufficient portfolio diversification. The HRT combines a Proximal Policy Optimization-based High-Level Controller for stock selection with a Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient-based Low-Level Controller for trade execution optimization. Empirical analysis shows the HRT achieves a higher Sharpe ratio than standalone DRL models and the S&P 500 benchmark across various market conditions, demonstrating improved profitability and robustness in automated stock trading.

title: MoA is All You Need :Building LLM Research Team using Mixture of Agents
abstract: This paper introduces Mixture of Agents (MoA), a Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) framework utilizing an ensemble of specialized small language model agents to enhance financial research. MoA addresses challenges in cost, speed, and output quality by structuring agents in collaborative hierarchies, mimicking organizational teams. The framework demonstrates improved response accuracy, grounding, and scalability compared to single-model approaches, making it viable for enterprise applications in investment management and financial analysis.

title: StockFormer: A Swing Trading Strategy Based on STL Decomposition and Self-Attention Networks
abstract: StockFormer is a deep learning framework designed for swing trading that integrates STL decomposition and self-attention networks to predict stock returns. The model uses S&P 500 data and features TopKDropout for improved stock selection. Tested from February to June 2023, it outperformed ten industry benchmarks in predictive accuracy metrics (MAE, RMSE, MAPE) with 62.39% trend detection accuracy. Backtesting showed a cumulative return of 13.19% and annualized return of 30.80%, surpassing state-of-the-art models. The framework is open-sourced to foster community collaboration.

title: SEMI-DECISION-FOCUSED LEARNING WITH DEEP ENSEMBLES: A PRACTICAL FRAMEWORK FOR ROBUST PORTFOLIO OPTIMIZATION
abstract: This paper introduces Semi-Decision-Focused Learning, a practical adaptation of Decision-Focused Learning for portfolio optimization. Instead of directly optimizing complex financial metrics like the Sharpe ratio, the method uses simple target portfolios (Max-Sortino or One-Hot) and trains models with a convex cross-entropy loss. Deep Ensemble techniques are incorporated to reduce variance and stabilize performance. Experiments on two market universes (upward-trending and range-bound) demonstrate consistent outperformance over baseline portfolios, highlighting the framework's effectiveness and robustness in real-world applications.

title: Quant5.0: Building AGI for Quantitative Investment
abstract: This paper introduces the Large Investment Model (LIM), a novel research paradigm addressing diminishing returns and high costs in traditional quantitative investment. LIM employs end-to-end learning and universal modeling to create an upstream foundation model that autonomously learns comprehensive signal patterns from diverse financial data across multiple exchanges, instruments, and frequencies. These global patterns are transferred to downstream strategy modeling for task-specific optimization. The paper details LIM's system architecture, technical challenges, and future research directions, with advantages demonstrated through numerical experiments on cross-instrument prediction for commodity futures trading using stock market insights.

title: ENHANCEMENT OF PRICE TREND TRADING STRATEGIES VIA IMAGE-INDUCED IMPORTANCE WEIGHTS
abstract: This paper introduces a novel weighted moving average method using image-induced importance (triple-I) weights derived from deep learning analysis of price chart images. The ResNet-based 'trader' identifies predictive price patterns via localization maps, which are used to weight existing technical trading signals (e.g., momentum, reversal) according to their importance in forecasting price movements. Empirical analysis on the Chinese stock market demonstrates that triple-I weighting significantly enhances portfolio performance, improving Sharpe ratios by up to 219% for certain strategies. The method also supports transfer learning across time scales and integration with non-technical strategies, validating its robustness and practical utility.

title: CausalStock: Deep End-to-end Causal Discovery for News-driven Stock Movement Prediction
abstract: This paper introduces CausalStock, a framework for news-driven multi-stock movement prediction that addresses two key challenges: discovering temporal causal relations between stocks and denoising news data. It employs a lag-dependent temporal causal discovery mechanism to model causal graph distributions and uses a Functional Causal Model for prediction. Additionally, it leverages large language models to score and extract useful information from noisy news text. Experiments on six real-world datasets across US, China, Japan, and UK markets show superior performance and explainability compared to baselines.

title: CALF: Aligning LLMs for Time Series Forecasting via Cross-modal Fine-Tuning
abstract: This paper introduces CALF, a cross-modal fine-tuning framework that addresses distribution discrepancies between textual and temporal data in LLM-based multivariate time series forecasting. The framework consists of temporal target and textual source branches with three alignment techniques: cross-modal match module for input distribution alignment, feature regularization loss for intermediate feature alignment, and output consistency loss for representation space alignment. CALF achieves state-of-the-art performance in both long-term and short-term forecasting tasks while maintaining low computational complexity and demonstrating strong few-shot and zero-shot generalization capabilities.

title: Alternative Loss Function in Evaluation of Transformer Models
abstract: This research investigates the application of the Mean Absolute Directional Loss (MADL) function for training and evaluating machine learning models in quantitative finance, specifically for algorithmic investment strategies. Through empirical experiments on equity and cryptocurrency assets, the study compares Transformer and LSTM models, demonstrating that Transformers significantly outperform LSTMs in most cases when using MADL. The methodology includes a walk-forward procedure to extend out-of-sample testing over 8-9 years, with performance evaluated via risk-adjusted returns and drawdown metrics.

title: Attention-Based Reading, Highlighting, and Forecasting of the Limit Order Book
abstract: This study introduces advanced sequence-to-sequence models to forecast the entire multi-level limit order book (LOB), including prices and volumes, addressing the complexity of high-frequency data. The key contribution is a compound multivariate embedding method that captures spatiotemporal relationships, outperforming existing models by achieving the lowest forecasting error while preserving LOB structure. The approach enhances predictive accuracy and market dynamics understanding, demonstrating the efficacy of attention-based architectures in high-frequency trading contexts.

title: DHMoE: Diffusion Generated Hierarchical Multi-Granular Expertise for Stock Prediction
abstract: This paper introduces DHMoE, a hierarchical mixture-of-experts model designed for stock prediction, addressing the limitations of single-predictor approaches in dynamic markets. It emulates top-down teaching and bottom-up decision-making workflows through a three-layer tree structure, where parameters are generated recursively. The top-level expert uses a Diffusion Inverted Transformer (DIT) to process multimodal inputs and allocate parameters to lower-level experts, which handle specific data modalities. Predictions are synthesized bottom-up for final outcomes. Experiments on NASDAQ, NYSE, and Ashare&HK datasets show superior cumulative and risk-adjusted returns compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: TIMEKAN: KAN-BASED FREQUENCY DECOMPOSITION LEARNING ARCHITECTURE FOR LONG-TERM TIME SERIES FORECASTING
abstract: TimeKAN introduces a novel architecture for long-term time series forecasting by decomposing mixed frequency components into distinct bands using cascaded frequency decomposition blocks. It leverages multi-order Kolmogorov-Arnold Networks (KAN) to flexibly model temporal patterns specific to each frequency, addressing varying information densities. The approach includes frequency mixing blocks to recombine components, achieving state-of-the-art performance with a lightweight design across multiple real-world datasets.

title: TEMPO: Prompt-Based Generative Pre-Trained Transformer for Time Series Forecasting
abstract: This paper introduces TEMPO, a novel prompt-based generative pre-trained transformer framework for time series forecasting. TEMPO addresses the challenge of adapting large pre-trained models to time series data by incorporating two key inductive biases: decomposition of time series into trend, seasonal, and residual components, and the use of soft prompts to facilitate distribution adaptation across different time series types. The model demonstrates superior performance in zero-shot settings on multiple benchmark datasets, including scenarios with unseen datasets and multimodal inputs. TEMPO's architecture enables effective representation learning and shows potential as a foundational framework for time series modeling.

title: UniTS: Building a Unified Time Series Model
abstract: UNITS is a unified time series model designed to handle multiple tasks—including forecasting, classification, imputation, and anomaly detection—across diverse domains using a single pretrained architecture. It employs a universal task specification via prompting, a data-domain agnostic network with sequence and variable attention, and a dynamic linear operator to manage heterogeneous data representations. Evaluated on 38 datasets, UNITS outperforms task-specific models and repurposed LLMs, demonstrating strong zero-shot, few-shot, and prompt learning capabilities without task-specific modules.

title: The Disappearing Index Effect
abstract: This paper examines the decline in the abnormal returns associated with stocks being added to or deleted from the S&P 500 index, from an average of 7.4% in the 1990s to near zero in the past decade. Despite increased indexation, the effect has diminished. The study explores four explanations: changes in firm composition, migrations between indices, front-running by arbitrageurs, and increased market liquidity. It concludes that migrations and enhanced liquidity are primary drivers, with limited roles for composition changes and front-running, offering implications for market efficiency.

title: Autoregressive Moving-Average Attention Mechanism for Time Series Forecasting
abstract: This paper introduces an Autoregressive Moving-Average (ARMA) attention structure that enhances linear attention mechanisms for time series forecasting by capturing both long-range and local temporal patterns. It demonstrates that decoder-only autoregressive Transformers, with proper tokenization and training, achieve performance comparable to state-of-the-art baselines. The proposed method integrates an MA term into AR attention without increasing computational complexity, using indirect weight generation to model short-term effects efficiently. Experimental results show consistent improvements across various AR attention models, achieving state-of-the-art forecasting accuracy.

title: TLOB: A Novel Transformer Model with Dual Attention for Price Trend Prediction with Limit Order Book Data
abstract: This paper introduces TLOB, a transformer-based model with dual attention for price trend prediction using limit order book (LOB) data. It addresses the limitations of existing models in generalizing across market conditions and assets. TLOB captures spatial and temporal dependencies adaptively, improving performance in volatile markets and longer horizons. A new labeling method reduces horizon bias. Evaluated on FI-2010, Tesla, Intel, and Bitcoin datasets, TLOB surpasses state-of-the-art by up to 7.7 F1-score. The study also notes declining predictability over time due to market efficiency and explores transaction cost integration.

title: Timing is Important: Risk-aware Fund Allocation based on Time-Series Forecasting
abstract: This paper addresses fund allocation in the time domain, where asset prices vary rapidly, by proposing the Risk-aware Time-Series Predict-and-Allocate (RTS-PnO) framework. It overcomes goal mismatch in naive prediction-only or Predict-then-Optimize approaches and handles uncertainty from state-of-the-art forecasting models. RTS-PnO features end-to-end training with objective alignment, adaptive uncertainty calibration, and model-agnostic design. Evaluated on eight financial datasets (Currency, Stock, Cryptos) and an online cross-border payment scenario at Tencent, it consistently outperforms baselines, reducing regret by 8.4% in real-world deployment.

title: DSPO: An End-to-End Framework for Direct Sorted Portfolio Construction
abstract: This paper introduces DSPO, an end-to-end deep learning framework for constructing characteristic-sorted portfolios directly from raw multi-frequency stock data. DSPO addresses limitations of traditional pipelined methods, such as manual feature engineering and misalignment between prediction and optimization objectives. It employs neural networks to model intra-timestep and inter-stock dependencies and introduces a Monotonical Logistic Regression loss to maximize the likelihood of optimal portfolio sorting. Empirical results on NYSE and A-Share markets show superior performance, with RankIC up to 10.12% and accumulated returns exceeding 121%, demonstrating robustness and scalability across thousands of stocks.

title: Enhancer: A Distribution-Aware Framework with Temporal-Relational Meta-Learning for Stock Prediction
abstract: This paper introduces Enhancer, a model-agnostic meta-learning framework for stock prediction that addresses temporal and relational distribution shifts in financial markets. The framework features two components: a Temporal Meta-Learner with Reactive Point Processes Attention to capture fine-grained temporal evolution, and a Relational Meta-Learner with an Approximation-Intervention mechanism to handle dynamic stock correlations. Experiments on four long-term stock datasets demonstrate Enhancer achieves 29.3% higher profit ratio and 18.54% higher Sharpe ratio compared to baselines in both stock trend prediction and investment recommendation tasks.

title: High-Throughput Asset Pricing
abstract: This paper applies empirical Bayes methods to systematically analyze 136,000 long-short trading strategies derived from accounting ratios, past returns, and ticker symbols. The approach, termed 'high-throughput asset pricing,' achieves out-of-sample performance comparable to top finance journals while eliminating look-ahead bias. Predictability is concentrated in accounting strategies, small stocks, and pre-2004 periods, aligning with limited attention theories. The study demonstrates that naive Sharpe ratio mining yields similar results, but empirical Bayes provides unbiased predictions and transparent insights. Multiple testing methods commonly used in finance fail to identify most performers, highlighting the need for rigorous data mining frameworks.

title: Forecasting Company Fundamentals
abstract: This paper addresses the forecasting of company fundamentals, which are crucial for assessing financial stability and investment decisions. The authors conduct a comprehensive evaluation of 22 deterministic and probabilistic forecasting models on real company data, comparing classical statistical methods with contemporary deep learning approaches. Results show that deep learning models outperform classical models, particularly in uncertainty estimation, and achieve accuracy comparable to human analysts. The study also demonstrates how these forecasts can enhance automated stock allocation and discusses methods for integrating domain expertise to improve reliability.

title: Pre-training Time Series Models with Stock Data Customization
abstract: This paper addresses the underexplored area of pre-training strategies for stock selection, focusing on adapting methods to the unique characteristics of financial data. It introduces three novel pre-training tasks: stock code classification, stock sector classification, and moving average prediction, designed to leverage stock-specific contextual information and address non-stationarity. The proposed Stock Specialized Pre-trained Transformer (SSPT) utilizes a two-layer architecture and demonstrates superior performance across five datasets, including multiple markets and time periods, outperforming benchmarks in cumulative investment return and Sharpe ratio. The study also provides insights into underlying mechanisms through simulated data experiments.

title: Dish-TS: A General Paradigm for Alleviating Distribution Shift in Time Series Forecasting
abstract: This paper addresses distribution shift in time series forecasting (TSF), which hinders model performance. It categorizes shifts into intra-space (within input-space) and inter-space (between input- and output-space). Dish-TS, a neural paradigm, uses a Dual-CONET framework with separate coefficient nets for input and output spaces to capture distribution differences. It includes a training strategy with prior knowledge for effective learning. Experiments show Dish-TS improves state-of-the-art models by over 20% on average.

title: DeepVol: Volatility Forecasting from High-Frequency Data with Dilated Causal Convolutions
abstract: This paper introduces DeepVol, a deep learning model utilizing dilated causal convolutions to forecast day-ahead volatility directly from high-frequency intraday data, bypassing the need for precomputed realized measures. By processing raw data, the model avoids information loss and microstructure noise issues inherent in traditional methods. Empirical evaluation on NASDAQ-100 data demonstrates superior accuracy over classical benchmarks, offering enhanced risk measures without manual feature engineering or model misspecification limitations.

title: Adaptive Quantitative Trading: An Imitative Deep Reinforcement Learning Approach
abstract: This paper introduces iRDPG, an adaptive quantitative trading model combining deep reinforcement learning (DRL) and imitation learning to address challenges in noisy high-frequency financial data and exploration-exploitation balance. The approach formulates trading as a Partially Observable Markov Decision Process (POMDP) and integrates imitation learning from classical strategies like Dual Thrust to enhance agent performance. Trained on minute-frequency market data, the model demonstrates robustness in feature extraction and adaptability across different financial markets, outperforming baseline strategies.

title: The Tabular Foundation Model TabPFN Outperforms Specialized Time Series Forecasting Models Based on Simple Features
abstract: This paper introduces TabPFN-TS, a method that applies the tabular foundation model TabPFN to time series forecasting through simple feature engineering. Without requiring pre-training on real-world time series data, TabPFN-TS leverages artificial data for pre-training, avoiding benchmark contamination. With only 11M parameters, it outperforms Chronos-Mini and matches or slightly exceeds the performance of Chronos-Large, which has 65 times more parameters. The approach demonstrates strong forecasting accuracy across diverse datasets, highlighting the generality and efficiency of tabular foundation models for time series tasks.

title: Stock Embeddings: Learning Distributed Representations for Financial Assets
abstract: This paper introduces a neural model for learning distributed representations (embeddings) of financial assets using historical returns data, inspired by distributional semantics in natural language processing. The approach captures nuanced relationships between stocks by analyzing return dynamics, enabling identification of similar and dissimilar assets for applications like portfolio optimization and diversification. Evaluations demonstrate the method's utility in financial analytics tasks, outperforming traditional correlation-based benchmarks.

title: Kronos: A Foundation Model for the Language of Financial Markets
abstract: Kronos is a unified, scalable pre-training framework designed specifically for financial candlestick (K-line) data, addressing limitations of existing Time Series Foundation Models (TSFMs) which often underperform on financial tasks. It introduces a specialized tokenizer that discretizes continuous market information into token sequences, preserving price dynamics and trade activity. Pre-trained autoregressively on over 12 billion K-line records from 45 global exchanges, Kronos excels in zero-shot settings, improving price forecasting RankIC by 93% over leading TSFMs and 87% over non-pre-trained baselines, while also achieving lower MAE in volatility forecasting and higher fidelity in synthetic data generation.

title: BPQP: A Differentiable Convex Optimization Framework for Efficient End-to-End Learning
abstract: This paper introduces BPQP, a differentiable convex optimization framework designed to enhance efficiency in end-to-end learning. It addresses the computational inefficiency of existing methods, which rely on costly implicit differentiation for gradient back-propagation through optimization layers. By reformulating the backward pass as a simplified, decoupled quadratic programming problem using structural properties of the KKT matrix, BPQP enables the use of first-order optimization algorithms and state-of-the-art solvers. Experiments on simulated and real-world datasets show that BPQP achieves up to an order of magnitude faster execution compared to baseline methods, making it suitable for large-scale applications like portfolio optimization.

title: Timer: Generative Pre-trained Transformers Are Large Time Series Models
abstract: This paper introduces Timer, a generative pre-trained transformer for large-scale time series analysis. It addresses performance bottlenecks in data-scarce scenarios by leveraging large-scale pre-training on up to 1 billion time points. The model unifies heterogeneous time series into a single-series sequence format and adapts a GPT-style architecture for next token prediction. Timer demonstrates few-shot generalization, scalability, and task versatility, achieving state-of-the-art results in forecasting, imputation, and anomaly detection through a unified generative approach.

title: Better by Default: Strong Pre-Tuned MLPs and Boosted Trees on Tabular Data
abstract: This paper addresses the performance gap between gradient-boosted decision trees (GBDTs) and neural networks on tabular data by introducing RealMLP, an enhanced multilayer perceptron, and optimized default parameters for both GBDTs and RealMLP. Using a meta-learning approach with 118 training and 90 test datasets, the study demonstrates that RealMLP offers competitive accuracy with faster training times compared to other neural baselines and is on par with GBDTs. The improved defaults enable strong out-of-the-box performance without hyperparameter tuning, and some enhancements also benefit TabR, showcasing broad applicability.

abstract: This paper investigates the application of transformer models to financial time series prediction. It constructs datasets for a synthetic mean-reverting Ornstein-Uhlenbeck process and real S&P500 data. The proposed transformer architecture, based on the encoder component, is detailed, incorporating positional encoding and probabilistic classification into predefined buckets. Results show accurate next-move prediction for synthetic data and promising outcomes for S&P500, particularly in quadratic variation and volatility forecasting, demonstrating the model's potential in financial contexts.

title: ALPHA2: DISCOVERING LOGICAL FORMULAIC ALPHAS USING DEEP REINFORCEMENT LEARNING
abstract: This paper introduces Alpha2, a framework for discovering formulaic alphas in quantitative trading using deep reinforcement learning (DRL). Unlike prior methods based on genetic programming, which suffer from sensitivity to initial conditions and slow computation, Alpha2 formulates alpha discovery as program construction. The DRL-guided agent assembles alpha programs optimized for performance and diversity, incorporating pre-calculation dimensional analysis to ensure logical soundness and prune the search space. Empirical results on real-world stock markets demonstrate that Alpha2 generates diverse, logical, and effective alphas, significantly improving trading strategy performance.

title: TIMESNET: TEMPORAL 2D-VARIATION MODELING FOR GENERAL TIME SERIES ANALYSIS
abstract: This paper introduces TimesNet, a novel framework for temporal variation modeling in time series analysis. The method addresses the challenge of capturing intricate temporal patterns by transforming 1D time series into 2D tensors based on multi-periodicity. This transformation embeds intraperiod and interperiod variations into columns and rows respectively, enabling effective modeling with 2D kernels. TimesNet employs TimesBlock to adaptively discover periods and extract variations using parameter-efficient inception blocks. The model achieves state-of-the-art performance across five key tasks: short- and long-term forecasting, imputation, classification, and anomaly detection.

title: Crossformer: Transformer Utilizing Cross-Dimension Dependency for Multivariate Time Series Forecasting
abstract: This paper introduces Crossformer, a Transformer-based model designed for multivariate time series (MTS) forecasting that explicitly captures cross-dimension dependency, which is often overlooked by existing models focused solely on temporal dependencies. The model employs Dimension-Segment-Wise (DSW) embedding to preserve time and dimension information in a 2D vector array and a Two-Stage Attention (TSA) layer to efficiently model both cross-time and cross-dimension relationships. Through a Hierarchical Encoder-Decoder (HED) structure, Crossformer leverages information at multiple scales for accurate forecasting. Extensive experiments on six real-world datasets demonstrate its superior performance over state-of-the-art methods.

title: HLOB – Information Persistence and Structure in Limit Order Books
abstract: This paper introduces HLOB, a novel large-scale deep learning model for forecasting mid-price changes in Limit Order Books. The architecture leverages an Information Filtering Network (Triangulated Maximally Filtered Graph) to uncover non-trivial dependencies among volume levels and incorporates deterministic design elements inspired by Homological Convolutional Neural Networks. Evaluated against nine state-of-the-art deep learning models on three real-world NASDAQ datasets (each with 15 stocks), HLOB demonstrates superior performance in specific scenarios. The study provides insights into the spatial distribution and temporal degradation of information in LOBs, bridging microstructural modeling and deep learning for high-frequency financial forecasting.

title: Optimizing Portfolio with Two-Sided Transactions and Lending: A Reinforcement Learning Framework
abstract: This study introduces a reinforcement learning (RL) framework for portfolio management in high-risk environments, specifically addressing the integration of two-sided transactions and lending. The model employs a Soft Actor-Critic (SAC) agent with a Convolutional Neural Network with Multi-Head Attention (CNN-MHA) architecture, utilizing a Profit and Loss (PnL)-based reward function to enhance downside risk management and capital optimization. Tested on a diversified 12-crypto asset portfolio in the Binance perpetual futures market with 4-hour rebalancing, the model outperformed benchmarks, especially in high-volatility scenarios, demonstrating superior return-to-risk ratios and robust profitability in cryptocurrency markets.

title: Fine-Tuning Large Language Models for Stock Return Prediction Using Newsflow
abstract: This paper investigates the fine-tuning of large language models (LLMs) for stock return forecasting using financial newsflow. It compares encoder-only (DeBERTa) and decoder-only (Mistral, Llama) LLMs to analyze how their distinct text representations affect prediction performance. Two methods for integrating token-level representations into forecasting modules are proposed: bottleneck and aggregated representations. Experiments on real news data and various investment universes show that aggregated representations improve portfolio performance, with decoder LLMs excelling in larger universes and Mistral demonstrating robustness. LLM-based predictions outperform conventional sentiment scores in portfolio construction.

title: LOB-Based Deep Learning Models for Stock Price Trend Prediction: A Benchmark Study
abstract: This paper benchmarks the robustness and generalizability of fifteen state-of-the-art deep learning models for stock price trend prediction using limit order book (LOB) data. The authors introduce LOBCAST, an open-source framework for data preprocessing, model training, evaluation, and profit analysis. Experiments reveal that while models perform well on the FI-2010 dataset, their performance significantly drops on unseen LOBSTER data, highlighting a simulation-to-reality gap and questioning real-world applicability. The study provides insights into current limitations and directions for future research.

title: DeepTraderX: Challenging Conventional Trading Strategies with Deep Learning in Multi-Threaded Market Simulations
abstract: This paper introduces DeepTraderX (DTX), a deep learning-based trader that learns from market data to generate bid/ask orders. Trained on historical limit order book data, DTX processes market states to determine order prices in a multi-threaded simulation environment. It was tested over 500 simulated market days against leading strategies, with statistical validation showing it often outperforms public-domain traders, including those surpassing human performance. The results highlight the efficiency of simple deep learning models in complex market simulations and their potential to enhance financial market efficiency.

title: OPERATOR DEEP SMOOTHING FOR IMPLIED VOLATILITY
abstract: This paper introduces a novel neural operator-based method for implied volatility smoothing, which constructs smooth surfaces from dynamically changing option market data. Unlike traditional parametric or neural network approaches requiring per-instance optimization, the proposed operator deep smoothing directly maps observed volatilities to smoothed surfaces using a single model. It adapts the graph neural operator architecture to handle varying input sizes and spatial arrangements, ensuring no-arbitrage constraints and robustness to input subsampling. Evaluated on ten years of intraday S&P 500 options data, the method outperforms industry benchmarks like SVI and classical neural networks, demonstrating strong generalization to other indices without retraining.

title: Enhancing Financial Market Predictions: Causality-Driven Feature Selection
abstract: This paper introduces the FinSen dataset, which integrates economic and financial news articles from 197 countries with stock market data over 15 years (2007–2023). Using causally validated sentiment scores and LSTM models, the study enhances market forecast accuracy and reliability. A novel Focal Calibration Loss reduces Expected Calibration Error to 3.34%, improving probabilistic alignment with real outcomes. The approach demonstrates the effectiveness of combining sentiment analysis with calibration techniques for trustworthy financial forecasting.

title: Optimising cryptocurrency portfolios through stable clustering of price correlation networks
abstract: This paper presents a technical framework for cryptocurrency portfolio optimization that integrates network analysis, price forecasting, and portfolio theory. The method uses Louvain community detection and consensus clustering to identify stable clusters of highly correlated cryptocurrencies from historical daily closing prices. An ARIMA model is employed for price prediction to ensure portfolio performance over a 14-day investment horizon. Empirical analysis over a 5-year period demonstrates that despite cryptocurrency market volatility, hidden price patterns can be effectively leveraged to generate consistently profitable, time-agnostic portfolios with minimized risk.

title: A Hierarchical conv-LSTM and LLM Integrated Model for Holistic Stock Forecasting
abstract: This paper introduces a novel two-level neural network integrating Conv-LSTM and a Large Language Model (LLM) for comprehensive stock forecasting. The first level uses convolutional layers to extract spatial patterns from historical stock prices and technical indicators, followed by LSTM layers to capture temporal dependencies. The second level incorporates an LLM to process and analyze textual data from financial news, social media, and reports for sentiment and contextual insights. This hybrid approach aims to enhance prediction accuracy and provide context-aware stock advising by combining numerical time-series analysis with unstructured text understanding.

title: RSAP-DFM: Regime-Shifting Adaptive Posterior Dynamic Factor Model for Stock Returns Prediction
abstract: This paper introduces RSAP-DFM, a novel dynamic factor model for stock returns prediction that adaptively extracts continuous macroeconomic information and dynamically maps it to stock returns through dual regime shifting. It employs a multi-head attention mechanism to generate factors from normal distributions and uses adversarial learning for posterior factor construction to correct mapping deviations. The model includes a two-stage optimization algorithm and normal sampling for enhanced robustness. Evaluated on real stock datasets, it achieves state-of-the-art performance, surpassing previous methods.

title: Beat the Market: An Effective Intraday Momentum Strategy for S&P500 ETF (SPY)
abstract: This paper investigates a simple intraday momentum strategy for the SPY ETF, which tracks the S&P 500. Unlike typical academic approaches that trade only in the last 30 minutes, this model initiates trend-following positions early based on abnormal demand/supply imbalances. It incorporates dynamic trailing stops to manage risk while maximizing upside. From 2007 to 2024, the strategy achieved a 1,985% total return (net of costs), 19.6% annualized return, and a Sharpe Ratio of 1.33. The study includes tests on market volatility regimes, dealer gamma imbalance effects, day-of-the-week profitability, and comparisons with technical patterns, while assessing the impact of transaction costs.

It emphasizes a gradual learning approach, minimizing jargon, and focusing on core programming concepts rather than language-specific details. The second edition includes updates for Python 3, additional exercises, case studies, debugging sections, and new chapters on advanced features. title: Multi-Graph Convolutional Network for Relationship-Driven Stock Movement Prediction
abstract: This paper proposes Multi-GCGRU, a deep learning framework combining Graph Convolutional Networks (GCN) and Gated Recurrent Units (GRU) for stock movement prediction. Unlike previous approaches that treat stocks independently, the model captures cross-effects among stocks by encoding multiple relationships (industry, shareholding, topical news) into graphs. GCN extracts cross-correlation features from these graphs, which are then combined with historical data and fed into GRU to model temporal dependencies. The model also explores data-driven adaptive relationships without prior financial knowledge. Experiments on Chinese stock indexes demonstrate superior performance over baselines.

title: Unified Training of Universal Time Series Forecasting Transformers
abstract: This paper introduces MOIRAI, a universal time series forecasting transformer designed to overcome the limitations of traditional one-model-per-dataset approaches. It addresses key challenges in cross-frequency learning, handling arbitrary multivariate dimensions, and accommodating varying distributional properties through novel architectural enhancements. Pre-trained on the LOTSA dataset with over 27 billion observations across nine domains, MOIRAI demonstrates competitive or superior zero-shot forecasting performance compared to full-shot models, enabling flexible and scalable application to diverse downstream tasks without dataset-specific training.

title: FlowHFT: Imitation Learning via Flow Matching Policy for Optimal High-Frequency Trading under Diverse Market Conditions
abstract: FlowHFT introduces a novel imitation learning framework using flow matching policy to address limitations of traditional high-frequency trading (HFT) models, which often fail under dynamic and volatile market conditions. By learning from multiple expert strategies proficient in specific scenarios, FlowHFT adaptively adjusts decisions and incorporates grid-search fine-tuning for superior performance. Evaluated across diverse market environments, it consistently outperforms individual expert strategies, demonstrating robustness to sudden price jumps and enabling rapid, millisecond-speed inference for real-time trading.

title: MERA: Mixture of Experts with Retrieval-Augmented Representation for Modeling Diversified Stock Patterns
abstract: This paper introduces MERA, a Mixture of Experts with Retrieval-Augmented Representation module, designed to address the challenge of modeling diverse stock patterns in quantitative investment. Unlike traditional single-branch models, MERA uses multiple independent experts for differentiated modeling and a GateNet to dynamically allocate data to the most suitable experts. To overcome the lack of explicit pattern identifiers, it leverages self-supervised pre-training to create high-level representations, retrieves similar samples, and uses their label information to guide allocation. Extensive experiments on real-world stock markets demonstrate significant performance improvements, and MERA is a plug-and-play module compatible with any deep learning-based model.

title: CI-STHPAN: Pre-trained Attention Network for Stock Selection with Channel-Independent Spatio-Temporal Hypergraph
abstract: This paper introduces CI-STHPAN, a two-stage framework for quantitative stock selection that addresses challenges of non-stationary dynamics and complex market dependencies. The method uses channel-independent processing to overcome distribution shift in financial time series and constructs dynamic hypergraphs based on stock similarity using Dynamic Time Warping. The framework employs Transformer and HGAT for self-supervised pre-training followed by stock-ranking fine-tuning. Experiments on NASDAQ and NYSE data over five years demonstrate superior performance in investment return ratio and Sharpe ratio compared to state-of-the-art approaches, with notable improvements in prediction accuracy and stability.

title: LEVERAGING DIFFUSION TRANSFORMERS FOR ROBUST STOCK FACTOR AUGMENTATION IN FINANCIAL MARKETS
abstract: This paper addresses data scarcity in stock forecasting by introducing DiffsFormer, a Transformer-based Diffusion Model that generates artificial intelligence-generated samples (AIGS) for data augmentation. Trained on a large-scale source domain with conditional guidance, it edits existing samples to control deviation from the target domain, enhancing downstream task performance. Evaluated on two datasets with eight machine learning models, DiffsFormer achieved relative improvements of 7.3% and 22.1% in excess return, demonstrating effectiveness in mitigating data scarcity and improving forecasting accuracy.
